results.title: Here comes Mr. Jordan
results.creator_credit: Alexander Hall, Everett Riskin and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Joe Pendleton (Robert Montgomery), is a contender for the light heavyweight boxing crown, but is killed in a plane crash. An angel (Edward Everett Horton), realising the error that Joe has arrived in heaven 50 years too early. Trying to rectify the mistake, Mr. Jordon (Claude Rains), the chief deispatcher of the “Heavenly Express” sends Joe back to earth in the body of a just-murdered millionaire. This delightful romantic comedy was so successful, it inspired a musical sequel, “Down to Earth” and was remade as “Heaven can wait” in 1978.

results.title: For me and my gal
results.creator_credit: Busby Berkeley, Arthur Freed and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Two of MGM’s brightest stars, Gene Kelly in his film debuty and Judy Garland, teamed in this Busby Berkeley musical about a vaudeville song-and-dance duo who buck tough times and World War I on the way to showbusiness success. The film has a collection of nostalgic gems including “Smiles”, “Ballin’ the Jack” and the title tune. Kelly’s inimitable dance style shines and Garland sustains her position as one of the greatest Hollywood legends. Bursting with energy, this is an old-fashioned musical for everyone who loves the movies.

results.title: Love story
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hiller, Howard G. Minsky and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Eric Segal’s best-selling novel adapted for the silver screen, became one of the most famous and loved “tear jerkers” of cinema history. Starring Ali MacGraw and Ryan O’Neal, they play a young college couple, Jenny and Oliver. The story chronicles their love as they overcome the obstacles of different social status, their marriage and ultimate separation when death claims Jenny. Nominated for seven Academy Awards, the film co-stars Ray Milland and John Marley. The haunting theme song became a hit classic of the movies.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Hiller, Howard G. Minsky and Paramount Pictures

results.title: Impromptu
results.creator_credit: James Lapine, Daniel A. Sherkow, Stuart Oken, Les Films Ariane, Governor Productions and Sovereign Pictures
results.brief_description: Two lovers could never be more different than the cross-dressing, cigar-smoking writer George Sand (Judy Davis) and the frail, romantic Frederic Chopin (Hugh Grant). The greatest creative minds of all time - including Liszt (Julian Sands), Delacroix (Ralph Brown) and de Musset (Mandy Patinkin) come together for one wild fortnight. The lustful Marie d’Agoult (Bernadette Peters) decides to amuse herself and with her mischievous scheming there is no telling who will end up with who! The outcome is scandalous even by today’s standards - an outrageous sex farce that portrays the greatest geniuses with sexual appetites as powerful as their creative fervour. Co-starring Georges Corraface, Anton Rodgers and Emma Thompson.

results.title: Heaven's gate
results.creator_credit: Michael Cimino, Joan Carell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Heaven’s gate is one of the most talked-about films in cinema history and based on events which occurred in Wyoming in 1892 when ruthless ranchers decided to kill starving immigrants who had been stealing cattle. Kris Kristofferson and Christopher Walken play lawman and hitman on opposite sides of the struggle, who share the love of Ella, played by Isabelle Huppert. The original film was cut by 70 minutes and was never acclaimed in the United States as it was in Europe. This version is presented in its entirety and has compelling performances by the supporting cast of John Hurt, Jeff Bridges and Sam Waterston and locational shoots of breathtaking beauty.

results.title: Hair
results.creator_credit: Milos Forman, Michael Butler, Lester Persky and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Despite the sceptics, Milos Forman transformed the ultimate “tribal rock musical” of the 1960’s into an exuberant film experience. The score is performed in a variety of locations including table tops, Central Park, Wall Street and in march formation aboard a plane heading for Vietnam. “Hair” is not just a nostalgic look at the ‘60’s and “The Age of Aquarius”, but the ideals it espouses about peace, individual freedom, joy and love are just as passionate and relevant today, as they were shocking and radical at the time of America’s involvement in Vietnam. Gerome Ragni and James Rado worked on this film production of their original stageplay.

results.title: Jesus Christ superstar
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Robert Stigwood and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice’s rock opera, “Jesus Christ Superstar” is one of the most successful theatrical musicals of all time. The story of Jesus’s Passion is scored to a vibrant, electronic rock beat and is performed by a cast of dancers and singers. The tribal aesthetics of the hippies and the counter-culture are as integral to the work as is the story of the Gospels. Filmed on location in Israel, the movie version of the opera is a pyrotechnic feast with dazzling editing and photography. Finally, however, it is the strength of the music and libretto by which this work has to be judged. The performances of Yvonne Elliman as Mary Magdalene and Carl Anderson as Judas are outstanding. Through their singing, the full tragedy and power of the Passion is realised. Songs include” “Jesus Christ Superstar”, “What’s the Buzz” and a knockout rendition of “I Don’t Know How to Love Him” by Elliman. Melvyn Bragg co-wrote the screenplay with Norman Jewison.

results.title: King of the hill
results.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, Ron Yerxa, Barbara Maltby, Albert Berger, Gramercy Pictures and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: After the post-modern dissection of contemporary sexual mores in “Sex, Lies and Videotape” this touching and elegant film, set in 1933 during the height of the Depression, is a wonderful surprise. Aaron (Jesse Bradford) is a young, imaginative Jewish boy whose father is an unemployed salesman and whose mother is hospitalised for tuberculosis. Initially, Aaron is relatively numbed to the devastations of poverty but as his own family descends further into unemployment, the safe confines of his world are slowly stripped away. “King of the Hill” is a homage to the romantic cinema of Capra and Wellman but it does not flinch from expressing the darker undercurrents of poverty. The supporting cast includes Jeroen Krabbe and Lisa Eichhorn as the parents, Karen Allen, Spalding Gray and Elisabeth McGovern. The soundtrack comprises popular songs of the thirties. Based on the Depression memoirs of A.E. Hotchner.

results.title: Funny face
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, Roger Edens and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Fred Astaire stars as a fashion photographer looking for a new face to promote Kay Thompson’s fashion magazine. He discovers Audrey Hepburn working in a bookstore and transforms her into a model on the cover of the “Vogue-like” magazine. Shot on location in Paris and featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin, “Funny face” is a song and dance delight, with romantic backdrops. Hepburn in her Givency clothes is stunning.

results.title: Last exit to Brooklyn (D)
results.creator_credit: Uli Edel, Bernard Eichinger, Allied Filmmakers and Bavaria Film
results.brief_description: Hubert Selby Jr’s controversial novel is a beat classic. This stark expressionist film manages to do the novel justice, contributing a visually electric night-landscape of a community going to hell. It is Brooklyn 1952 and a six month factory strike has accelerated poverty and despair in the working-class white suburbs. “Last Exit to Brooklyn” reveals the hidden subcultures and tensions in poor American communities, a subject rarely addressed by Hollywood. The narrative whirlwinds around a trio of stories: Ricky Lake plays a young Italian girl who falls pregnant, to the distress of her Italo-American father. Stephen Lang is a union organiser, skirting corruption, whose attraction to men begins to dismantle the safe complacency of his masculinity as he encounters the underground homosexual world of the 1950s. Jennifer Jason Leigh delivers a tragically sublime performance as Tra-La-La, a beautiful young woman who is used, abused and exploited by a young gang of pimps. This is a dark, terrifying movie; shattering the myth of American equality. The final gang assault of Tra-La-La is one of the most violent, distressing scenes in cinema and the film was initially banned in Australia. Music by Mark Knopfler.
